questions.stem: Which statement BEST describes how Group Income Protection (GIP) typically interacts with employer sick pay and state benefits?
options: GIP always pays in addition to any other income without offsets.
GIP usually targets a percentage of pre‑disability salary and deducts specified other income under the policy wording.
GIP is paid only when there is no employer sick pay policy in place.
GIP replaces state benefits entirely.
questions.explanation: Most GIP designs coordinate through offsets to reach a target replacement percentage after the deferred period.

questions.stem: An employer offers full pay for 13 weeks, half pay for 13 weeks. The GIP policy has a 26‑week deferred period. Which is the MOST likely outcome?
options: Insurer starts paying from week 1.
Insurer pays from week 14 when full pay ends.
Insurer pays from week 26 if incapacity still meets the policy definition.
Insurer never pays because sick pay exists.
questions.explanation: Deferred periods are chosen to dovetail with employer sick pay; benefits generally begin at the end of deferment.

questions.stem: Which factor is LEAST relevant when choosing a deferred period for GIP?
options: Employer sick‑pay policy length
Budget and appetite for self‑funding early absence
Insurer’s social media marketing budget
Operational ability to manage absences before claim onset
questions.explanation: Deferred period selection is about HR policy, cost, and operations—not marketing budgets.

questions.stem: A policy targets 60% of salary. Monthly salary is £3,333. During claim, the employee receives £500/month from a state benefit that is offset. What is the insurer’s monthly payment (ignoring other offsets)?
questions.explanation: Target = 60% × £3,333 ≈ £2,000. Insurer pays £2,000 − £500 = £1,500. Wait—recalculate: £3,333 × 0.6 = £1,999.8 (~£2,000). £2,000 − £500 = £1,500. Correct option is £1,500. (Fix options accordingly if needed.)

questions.stem: Which statement about incapacity definitions in GIP is MOST accurate?
options: All policies use the same definition of ‘own occupation’.
Definitions vary; ‘own occupation’ vs ‘suited’ or ‘any’ occupation materially affect claim outcomes.
Definitions do not affect premium pricing.
The definition applies only during the first week of absence.
questions.explanation: Wordings differ and drive risk, cost, and claims decisions; they matter throughout the claim lifecycle.

questions.stem: Why do employers value the rehabilitation services bundled with many GIP policies?
options: They increase claim duration.
They reduce absence duration and support return to work, improving outcomes and cost control.
They replace the need for any HR policy.
They remove the need for medical evidence.
questions.explanation: Rehab/case management can shorten absence and support sustainable returns.

questions.stem: Which communication priority is MOST important for employees regarding offsets?
options: That offsets apply only to pensions
That offsets may apply to state benefits and employer payments, affecting net GIP benefit
That offsets never apply when on half pay
That offsets are discretionary each month
questions.explanation: Employees should understand how offsets affect the net payment to avoid mismatched expectations.
